013package org.postgresql.pljava.example.annotation;
014
015import java.sql.Connection;
016import static java.sql.DriverManager.getConnection;
017import java.sql.SQLException;
018import java.sql.Statement;
019
020import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.Function;
021import org.postgresql.pljava.annotation.SQLType;
022
023/**
024 * Illustrates how not to handle an exception thrown by a call into PostgreSQL.
025 *<p>
026 * Such an exception must either be rethrown (or result in some higher-level
027 * exception being rethrown) or cleared by rolling back the transaction or
028 * a previously-established savepoint. If it is simply caught and not propagated
029 * and the error condition is not cleared, no further calls into PostgreSQL
030 * functionality can be made within the containing transaction.
031 *
032 * @see <a href="../../../../../../../../use/catch.html">Catching PostgreSQL exceptions
033 * in Java</a>
034 */
035public interface MishandledExceptions
036{
037    /**
038     * Executes an SQL statement that produces an error (twice, if requested),
039     * catching the resulting exception but not propagating it or rolling back
040     * a savepoint; then throws an unrelated exception if succeed is false.
041     */
042    @Function(schema = "javatest")
043    static String mishandle(
044        boolean twice, @SQLType(defaultValue="true")boolean succeed)
045    throws SQLException
046    {
047        String rslt = null;
048        do
049        {
050            try
051            (
052                Connection c = getConnection("jdbc:default:connection");
053                Statement s = c.createStatement();
054            )
055            {
056                s.execute("DO LANGUAGE \"no such language\" 'no such thing'");
057            }
058            catch ( SQLException e )
059            {
060                rslt = e.toString();
061                /* nothing rethrown, nothing rolled back <- BAD PRACTICE */
062            }
063        }
064        while ( ! (twice ^= true) );
065
066        if ( succeed )
067            return rslt;
068
069        throw new SQLException("unrelated");
070    }
071}
